titleStmt.title: Revisions to Henry David Thoreau's manuscript of Walden

publicationStmt.p: Final Project for ENGL 340, Literature and Literary Study in the Digital Age, Spring 2020, SUNY Geneseo.

sourceDesc.bibl: A page from HM 924, the manuscript of Walden, "Higher Laws", Paragraph 1, Version E

zone.note: Looking at the revisions in what use to be the seventh and ending paragraph of the Higher Laws chapter of Walden documents the changes Thoreau makes to make this section more general and applicable to everyone. Thoreau changes words that apply directly to him to words that apply to everyone, showing that, true to the chapters name Higher Laws, what Thoreau is discussing applys to everyone, not just himself.
zone.line: If I listen one listens to the faintest but constand suggestions of my
his genius, which are certainly true, I see he sees not to what
extremes or even insanity it would lead me may lead him and yet
that way as I grow he grows more resolute and faithful my his road
lies The faintest assured objection which one healthy man feels will
at length prevail over the arguments and customs of mankind. No
man ever followed his genius till it misled him. Though the result
were bodily weakness, yet no man one perhaps can say that the
consequences were to be regretted, for these were a life in
conformity to higher principles. If the day and the night are such that
you greet them with joy, and life emits a fragrance like flowers and
sweet-scented herbs, is more elastic, more starry, more immortal,â€”
that is your success. All nature is your congratulation, and you have
cause momentarily to bless yourself. The greatest gains and values
are farthest from being appreciated. We easily come to doubt if they
exist. We soon forget them. Perhaps the
facts most astounding and most real are never communicated by
man to man. The true harvest of my daily life is somewhat as
intangible and indescribable as the tints of morning or evening. It is a
little star-dust caught, a segment of the rainbow which I have
clutched.
